subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... Yes.  It takes real effort to become aware of purely allophonic distinctions.  The phoneme in shutter is /t/, no matter how pronounced. ... Checking the
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> This raises a very good point. I (Californian) personally sound D for
> T in "shutter" yet it is natural for me to use Tea correctly in these
> cases. Indeed it would take a extra mental effort to use Day in
> "shutter" and thereby accurately reflect my own noise.

Yes. It takes real effort to become aware of purely allophonic
distinctions. The phoneme in "shutter" is /t/, no matter how pronounced.

> It is probable that changing the D to T in such cases in the CMU still
> reflects a real world accent. Indeed I too believe this would be a
> good thing.

Checking the CMU, it already provides T -- the question was whether it
should be fixed to provide D instead. I think the consensus is "no".

BTW, I was wrong earlier when I claimed that CMU was wrongly using AH
instead of A. There is no A as such, there is only AA (Ah or Ox), AE
(At), AH (Utter), AO (Awe), AW (Owe), and AY (I). The general rule
in CMU-ese is that A, E, I, O, and U are always followed by a second
letter, and that H is always preceded by one (thus /h/ is HH). It is
always possible to segment strings of CMU-ese into the 39 letters and
digraphs unambiguously.

--
Samuel Johnson on playing the violin: John Cowan
"Difficult do you call it, Sir? cowan@...
I wish it were impossible." http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
